question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds on Earth. If the pendulum is taken to a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is 4 times that of Earth, what will be the new period of the pendulum?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. The period is inversely proportional to the square root of g. If g becomes 4 times larger, the period will be halved. Using the formula, we get: T_new = 2π√(L/(4g)) = (2π√(L/g)) / √4 = T_Earth / 2 = 2 seconds / 2 = 0.5 seconds.
